awd_titl_txt: Integrating Computational Thinking into Mathematics Instruction in Rural and Urban Preschools
awd_abstract_narration:
The STEM+Computing Partnership (STEM+C) program seeks to advance multidisciplinary integration of computing in STEM teaching and learning through applied research and development across one or more domains. This project will conduct exploratory research to better understand how preschool learning and instructional environments can be designed to support the integration of computational thinking (CT) with mathematics for children ages 4-5. Although recent research suggests that young children can master computational thinking concepts such as sequencing, repeat loops, and setting parameters, there is limited research about how this understanding could intersect with other STEM disciplines such as science, engineering, and mathematics. This project will investigate children's CT learning and teachers' understanding of CT as they engage with playful prototypes of hands-on activities and digital tablet apps that align with preschool math instruction. The development of preschool CT learning models and CT learning tasks will be used to assess children's CT thinking and will contribute to an understanding around how CT skills may develop in young children.

Working in close collaboration with 16 preschool educators and 100-120 diverse rural and urban children in four public preschools in eastern Kentucky, Boston, and New York, learning researchers and media designers will explore how young children make sense of computational thinking (CT) practices in the context of mathematics instruction. This two-year research and development process will be modeled on Clements's (2007) Curriculum Research Framework and will: 1) explore foundational research in early childhood math and CT, consult with expert advisors, and conduct stakeholder interviews with teachers working in under-served urban and rural preschool settings to understand the learning opportunities that could arise when CT is infused into existing preschool mathematical practice; 2) draft preschool CT learning models that will inform development of CT activity prototypes and a playful set of CT learning tasks to explore preschoolers' CT learning; 3) conduct a formative research process to explore children's CT learning and teachers' CT understanding as they engage with prototype hands-on activities and digital tablet apps aligned with concepts taught in the NSF-funded Building Blocks preschool math curriculum, and; 4) evaluate preschool children's learning using the Research-Based Early Math Assessment to understand how their performance on the CT learning tasks corresponds to their learning of mathematics. In future, these preschool resources could be further developed and contribute to the need for high-quality, research-based approaches to preschool instruction and learning.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Public media producers from WGBH and Kentucky Educational Television and researchers from Education Development Center teamed up on the project Integrating Computational Thinking (CT) into Mathematics Instruction in Rural and Urban Preschools (DRL 1640135). Modeled on Clements's (2007) Curriculum Research Framework, the project team developed a learning blueprint and an alignment document stating relationships between the learning goals and preschool math instruction. The team then used these foundational documents to iteratively develop and test prototypes of 3 digital tablet apps and 12 hands-on activities that focused on the CT core ideas of sequencing, debugging, and modularity in ways that leverage children's math skills. Researchers also engaged in an iterative development process for creating CT learning tasks.

 

After classroom observations with 16 teachers in rural and urban preschools, researchers analyzed observation notes and identified promising practices and areas for improvement for the prototypes. Videos from the classroom visits were analyzed for children's CT learning and teachers' CT understanding related to the CT skills of debugging, modularity, and sequencing. EDC researchers administered three CT learning tasks (each addressing one of the CT core ideas (sequencing, debugging, modularity) to a sample of preschool students, which were analyzed using descriptive and qualitative methods to understand how children typically approached these problem/goal-based tasks.

 

Very few studies have focused on how CT can be explored with young children in formal learning environments. This exploratory study provides promising evidence to show that, through a combination of hands-on activities and digital apps, educators can generate meaningful experiences for preschool children to explore CT by leveraging their existing mathematical knowledge. Further, very few studies have explored how to introduce CT to early childhood educators. The evidence from classroom observations shows that teachers have varying levels of comfort in providing supports that enhance children's ability to use their CT skills. Our work suggests that teacher training and supports, specifically focused on how CT is already a part of everyday classroom activities and how certain types of teacher scaffolding can enhance these learning opportunities, might create higher levels of comfort and confidence in early childhood educators. Finally, very few studies have begun the difficult process of creating assessments of CT for early childhood, particularly in children that are still developing their verbal communication skills. Our hands-on tasks, situated in real-world problems, show promise, but more work is needed to identify precise evaluative criteria that allow us to reliably assess children's current CT abilities. 

 

The team has made valuable contributions to the field on how to support CT exploration in young children and how to design high-quality CT learning experiences for preschool classrooms, yielding valuable evidence for some of the conventions that may support a developmentally appropriate approach. As part of our research, we have explored the following topics, offering recommendations for future research and development efforts:

 

  • Aligning CT activities to the types of mathematical skills that are already part of a preschool math curriculum appears to work well as the basis for integrating CT into preschool mathematics.
  • Creating a general framework for how CT classroom activities are explored may provide opportunities for teachers to develop a schema for supporting children during these types of activities.
  • Utilizing specific design strategies in the development of CT activities can support children's exploration of complex problems, promote processing, and highlight the use of the CT core ideas. 

 

Our project's iterative development of CT learning tasks and analysis of children's performance also highlighted important considerations. The field needs CT assessments for young children that: (1) are as authentic as possible, asking children to solve relatable, real-world problems; (2) provide for open-ended responses to showcase children's abilities to use CT skills; and (3) allow the assessor to document not only children's ability to solve a problem, but also the process with which they approach problem-solving.
